Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Participants of “The People vs The State of TN” march in front of the capitol in Nashville on April 17.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Participants of “The People vs The State of TN” march in front of the capitol in Nashville on April 17.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It just shortens the whole timeline in which a person can lose their home,” said Brian Rees, a staff attorney at The Works Inc. nonprofit who has represented hundreds of tenants in eviction proceedings in recent years.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: staff attorney at The Works Inc. nonprofit
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who has represented hundreds of tenants in eviction proceedings in recent years

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: House Bill 2267, which cut tenants’ right to a continuance in half, hadn’t yet been signed by Gov. Bill Lee. If the governor signed it, Henderson said, it would have “devastating” consequences for renters.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who judges thousands of eviction cases per year

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Landlords have always had a very strong lobbying group,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who judges thousands of eviction cases per year

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Sen. Art Swann (R-Maryville), who sponsored the legislation in the Senate, provided MLK50 with a statement but did not respond to follow-up questions.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who sponsored the legislation in the Senate

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: In the statement, Swann said the bill will help landlords free up apartments more quickly for the thousands of Tennesseeans seeking a home.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who sponsored the legislation in the Senate

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: He also said it would help the apartment industry develop new apartments, but he didn’t make clear how it would.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who sponsored the legislation in the Senate

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: While the difference of a week may not seem like much, Rees said it can really matter for these renters since the pathways to avoiding eviction can take time to figure out.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: staff attorney at The Works Inc. nonprofit
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who has represented hundreds of tenants in eviction proceedings in recent years

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It’s disheartening to see them make a change that will affect families who are struggling,” Rees said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: staff attorney at The Works Inc. nonprofit
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who has represented hundreds of tenants in eviction proceedings in recent years

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: This session, Thompson thought he had a shot at amending state law to let Memphis join its peer in Middle Tennessee — until he realized the Tennessee Association of Realtors was dead set against him, no matter what compromises he offered them.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who sought to amend state law to let Memphis join its peer in Middle Tennessee

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “(TAR) has the connection with a lot of legislators, especially on the commerce committee, where this was going to be,” Thompson said. “(And) they were just ironclad.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who sought to amend state law to let Memphis join its peer in Middle Tennessee

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Thompson told the subcommittee that registration had worked well for Nashville but failed to convince them.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who sought to amend state law to let Memphis join its peer in Middle Tennessee

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “How are you going to find the (bad actors)? It looks to me like the good people will do it but the bad people aren’t going to change,” Marsh said during the subcommittee hearing.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who spoke during the subcommittee hearing

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Given TAR’s opposition and the legislature itself having recently moved “much farther to the right,” in his experience, Thompson said a Shelby County rental registry is “probably not in the cards, for several years anyway.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who sought to amend state law to let Memphis join its peer in Middle Tennessee

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Thompson was able to pass one bill this year he thinks will help tenants.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who sought to amend state law to let Memphis join its peer in Middle Tennessee

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Assuming the bill is signed by Lee, it will require landlords to provide tenants with a phone number or online portal they can use to make maintenance requests.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who sought to amend state law to let Memphis join its peer in Middle Tennessee

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: While most landlords do this already, Thompson said he’s heard from tenants who tell him they have no way of contacting their landlord or property manager about maintenance issues.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who sought to amend state law to let Memphis join its peer in Middle Tennessee

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Still, Rees sees the legislation’s passage as a win.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: staff attorney at The Works Inc. nonprofit
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who has represented hundreds of tenants in eviction proceedings in recent years

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I really am happy to see that pass,” Rees said. “I think it’s important that tenants do have good quality contact information for their property manager or owner.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: staff attorney at The Works Inc. nonprofit
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: who has represented hundreds of tenants in eviction proceedings in recent years

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The Tennessee Association of Realtors is the sixth largest spender on Tennessee politics, according to the Tennessee Lookout’s database, having spent $6.5 million on lobbying, campaign donations and other political expenditures since 2009.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The Tennessee Association of Realtors is the sixth largest spender on Tennessee politics, according to the Tennessee Lookout’s database, having spent $6.5 million on lobbying, campaign donations and other political expenditures since 2009.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The Tennessee Association of Realtors has been Swann’s top funder since the start of 2009, according to the Tennessee Lookout, giving him $18,750.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The Tennessee Association of Realtors has been Swann’s top funder since the start of 2009, according to the Tennessee Lookout, giving him $18,750.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: It has also given Boyd $11,500 since 2009, making it his No. 6 funder.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: It has also given Boyd $11,500 since 2009, making it his No. 6 funder.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: TAR representatives did not return a pair of phone calls from MLK50.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: TAR representatives did not return a pair of phone calls from MLK50.
